TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr GPE is a NORP citizen who has been living in GPE since DATE .
CARDINAL . In DATE , after proceedings had been instituted against the applicant with a view to his confinement in a psychiatric hospital , he was provisionally detained in such an institution .

On DATE ORG ( Landgericht ) , before which the applicant was represented by officially - appointed counsel , ordered that he be detained in a psychiatric hospital , pursuant to LAW . The court found that he had performed acts which constituted criminal offences ( insulting behaviour , assault occasioning bodily harm , resisting the police , causing a traffic hazard and unauthorised departure from the scene of an accident ) but that he could not be held responsible because he was suffering from a schizophrenic psychosis with signs of paranoia . Relying in particular on a medical expert ’s opinion , the court stated that ORG posed a danger to the general public because it had to be expected that he would commit further serious unlawful acts .

The court considered that his mental illness was so obvious that it was not necessary to order an expert opinion on the point .

In the latter decision the court found that Mr GPE ’s delusions had become more severe and suggested that guardianship proceedings ( GPE ) be instituted against him .

On DATE Mr Megyeri , who had tried to have the criminal proceedings against him ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) reopened , asked ORG to replace the lawyer who had acted for him in those proceedings ; he also asked why that lawyer had not been present when his detention had subsequently been reviewed . The court informed him in writing , on DATE , that there was no legal provision to the effect that counsel had to be officially assigned to detainees in review proceedings .

It relied in particular on a written report by CARDINAL experts , including CARDINAL doctors from the hospital , according to which Mr GPE ’s state of mental health had further deteriorated , he was not willing to undergo treatment and he showed a distinct propensity towards aggressive behaviour and violence . It also relied on its own impression of the applicant , formed when it heard him on DATE , on which occasion he had made numerous complaints and claimed to be someone else . Referring to recent case - law of ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , ORG considered that the applicant ’s continued detention was proportionate to the aim pursued , that is the protection of the public . The applicant was not represented by counsel in the DATE proceedings concerning his possible release . According to ORG , it was to be assumed , since NORP law required the appointment of counsel in certain circumstances , that those courts had considered the matter of their own motion .

CARDINAL . The following provisions of LAW ) are relevant in the present case .

Suspension shall be followed by supervision of conduct . "

CARDINAL . According to case - law of ORG ( decision of CARDINAL DATE - CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL - Entscheidungssammlung des Bundesverfassungsgerichts , vol . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL et seq . ) , the principle of proportionality governs the detention of a person in a psychiatric hospital and its continuance . When deciding whether to suspend on probation the further execution of such detention , the court has to consider in particular the risk of significant ( erhebliche ) criminal offences , the detainee ’s previous conduct and criminal behaviour , relevant changes in the circumstances since his detention was ordered and the detainee ’s future living conditions . The longer the detention in a psychiatric hospital lasts , the stricter the test of proportionality becomes .

CARDINAL . The question of the defence of an accused by counsel is governed by LAW ) . Paragraph CARDINAL lists a number of specific cases in which the participation of counsel is obligatory ; paragraph CARDINAL provides :

" In other cases , the presiding judge , upon request or ex officio , shall appoint a defence counsel if , having regard to the seriousness of the crime or the difficulty of the factual or legal issues involved , the assistance of a defence counsel appears to be necessary , or if it is obvious that the accused can not defend himself ... "
Paragraph CARDINAL is applied by analogy to review proceedings under LAW .
